  "translated_text": "The truth-finding and liquidation of past issues is emerging as an issue across various sectors of society and culture.

Recently, the film 'The Man Then' dealing with former President Park Chung-hee's October 26 incident [the 1979 assassination of Park Chung-hee] held a preview screening, and the replacement of his handwritten plaque at Gwanghwamun [Seoul's main gate] is also being pursued.

Whether figures who were revered as leaders of the nation during the Japanese colonial period engaged in pro-Japanese activities is also on many people's lips. Inchon Kim Seong-su is one of them.

Amidst this situation, an article by Lee Cheol-seung, Representative Standing Chairman of the Liberal Democratic National Conference, detailing Inchon's activities around liberation, particularly the circumstances surrounding the student soldier issue at that time, has been published in Monthly Chosun and is drawing attention.

This article titled 'Lee Cheol-seung's Memories' is introduced in its original form. <Editor's Note>

Lee Cheol-seung's Memories

▽Meeting a Leader of the Nation▽

Born in an anti-Japanese family, from my days at Jeonju Bukjung [Jeonju North Middle School, predecessor of Jeonju High School], I did not undergo the Japanese-imposed name change [creating Japanese-style names], did not speak the 'national language' (Japanese), and beat up Japanese students who discriminated against Koreans, receiving home detention or suspension, ultimately failing the second year.

In 1942, during my fifth-year graduation class, I caused an incident by throwing a Japanese teacher named Noda to the classroom floor after he said 'Hangeul is a code used by savages' and extremely despised Koreans. Branded as an unruly Korean student, I became unable to pursue Japanese study abroad or enter government/public professional colleges, which were perceived as paths to success.

My uncle Lee Seok-ju (a member of the Constitutional Assembly) advised: 'If you go to Japan for study or enter government/public schools, with your bad ideology you'll easily spend your life repeatedly in prison or fall into becoming a delinquent. Therefore, enroll in Bosung Professional School [predecessor of Korea University], a national school established by our own strength, under the leadership of our nation's leader.' Following this advice, I entered Bosung Professional School. At that time, Inchon Kim Seong-su was serving as principal, so I came to serve the teacher closely.

Inchon graduated from Waseda University in Japan in 1914 and, with the belief in 'nation-building through education' that many talented people must be cultivated for the indefinite independence of the homeland, took over Jungang School [predecessor of Jungang High School] and became principal in 1917. In 1932, when Bosung Professional School, established by Lee Yong-ik in 1905, faced financial difficulties, he took it over and became principal. Whenever I visit my alma mater, I recall the image of Inchon wearing a straw hat and pulling weeds on the lawn beneath what is now Korea University's Inchon statue.

▽Inchon Never Encouraged Student Soldier Volunteering▽

At that time, Bosung Professional had Principal Kim Seong-su from the nationalist camp, along with Jang Deok-su, Ahn Ho-sang, Yu Jin-o, Jin Seung-rok, and Son Jin-tae, as well as Yun Haeng-jung, Park Geuk-chae, and Choi Yong-dal from the socialist camp.

Though they differed in ideology, under Inchon these people cooperated in anti-Japanese activities without conflict, nurturing the younger generation and planting and cultivating seeds of independent liberation. After liberation, they immediately split into left and right-wing camp leaders, playing leading roles in their respective camps. At that time and place, our Bosung Professional was like 'a hometown for young people filled with the fragrance of the nation.'

There is one anecdote to introduce here. In 1930, Inchon visited his father Kim Gyeong-jung in his hometown of Gochang, North Jeolla Province, and recommended the takeover of Bosung Professional several times, but his father refused each time. Following the advice of Song Jin-u and Baek Gwan-su, Inchon decided to bring his father to Seoul unconditionally and had Jungang High School students and Bosung Professional students give a grand welcome at Seoul Station platform.

When Kim arrived at Seoul Station, there was a grand welcome by Jungang High School students and some Bosung Professional students. Kim was surprised but also showed a satisfied expression. Kim then agreed to the takeover of the financially troubled Bosung Professional and contributed enormous wealth to make the Bosung Professional takeover possible.

When the Student Volunteer System was implemented on October 20, 1943, the Government-General of Korea mobilized police, military police, and other administrative agencies at all levels of professional college authorities to force student soldier volunteering. When their volunteering results were poor, they mobilized leading figures to force student soldier encouragement. Choi Nam-seon and Lee Gwang-su encouraged student soldier volunteering not only domestically but even went to Tokyo, Japan, and Yun Chi-ho encouraged by saying 'A glorious path has opened for Korean students to stand shoulder to shoulder with Japanese compatriots and go to the battlefield.'

What was Inchon's position in this situation? Despite Japanese pressure, Inchon said, 'I was entrusted with their education, not to tell them to go or not go to the battlefield.' However, a reporter from the Government-General organ 'Maeil Sinbo' published an article selling Inchon's name without permission to flatter the Japanese. Later, when I was dragged away as a student soldier, I never heard Inchon tell us we should go as student soldiers until the day we departed.

Goha Song Jin-u, who was Inchon's close friend and president of Dong-A Ilbo at the time, also completely avoided student soldier encouragement campaigns, using illness treatment as an excuse.

One day when I visited Inchon, Song said, 'The Japanese rushing student soldier volunteering is evidence that the war situation is that unfavorable for them. It seems they want to use this opportunity to eliminate the educated Korean seeds. Act wisely.' So I decided to conduct a student soldier refusal movement nationwide during winter vacation.

On another day, when I visited Professor Ahn Ho-sang, who was hospitalized feigning illness, with classmate Yun Won-gu, he pulled my ear and said, 'Defeat is certain, avoid it.'

I immediately resolved with Lee Hyeok-gi from Gyeongseong Imperial University [who became commander of the leftist Korean Military Preparation Corps immediately after liberation] at the boarding house of a student from Yonhui Professional School to organize and strongly develop this student soldier refusal movement.

▽Inchon Was Too Difficult Even for the Governor-General to Handle▽

However, this secret leaked through a student Kim from Hyehwa Professional School and was reported to Governor-General Koiso through a pro-Japanese leader named Mun, who was Kim's relative. Perhaps sensing the seriousness of the matter, he immediately requested a meeting with our representatives through Mun.

After heated discussion, we decided to attend the meeting, and the meeting with the Governor-General took place. We went with grave resolve, dividing up key questions.

We argued, 'Japan calls it a Holy War for Greater East Asia and recognizes independence for all other Southeast Asian countries, so why won't it grant independence to 20 million Koreans? Going to war without national independence is like dying a dog's death. Therefore, we will risk our lives to develop a student soldier refusal movement.'

Governor-General Koiso raised his voice, saying, 'Korea and Japan share the same ancestry and roots [dongjo-donggŭn]. Therefore Korea and Japan must become one [naeseon-ilche]. Your words have merit. That's why I called you. Resolving Korean dissatisfaction is precisely my duty.' Koiso looked at me intently and asked, 'Which school, who are you?'

I answered loudly, 'I am Lee Cheol-seung from Bosung Professional.' He examined me once more from various angles and muttered as if to himself, 'Kim Seong-su is an impeccable person.'

I instantly thought, 'Inchon is someone even the Governor-General finds difficult to handle.' I pressed him, asking, 'Will Bosung Professional also be closed in this professional college reorganization?' but could not get a clear answer. We told the Governor-General's persuasion, 'We don't understand. We're going back now,' speaking loudly and left the Governor-General's residence.

Afterward, in 1944, the Government-General of Korea could not close Bosung Professional and changed Bosung Professional to Gyeongseong Colonial Economic Professional, Yonhui Professional to Gyeongseong Industrial Management Professional, and Ewha Women's Professional and Sookmyung Women's Professional to agricultural extension training centers. Gyeongseong Law Professional, Myeongryun Professional, and Hyehwa Professional were closed. In the end, Korea's professional colleges also underwent forced name changes.

▽Justice Will Be Realized▽

The farewell ceremony held on December 5, 1944, was an event to send off us who were departing on a path to death. Mrs. Lee A-ju (Inchon's wife) and Mrs. Park Eun-hye (Jang Deok-su's wife) also attended this farewell ceremony. Inchon sat in the principal's office with a sullen expression until the ceremony began, then went up to the podium when it started and said in anguish, 'I was entrusted with your education, not your military service, yet we have gathered like this today.'

Student supervisor Jang Deok-su said, 'Your going to war is an unspeakable tragedy. But to put it differently, this is the first time our young people will hold guns and receive collective training and act together. So don't think only that you're going to die, but think that you're going to train your mind and body for our tomorrow.'

Then Dr. Ahn Ho-sang said, 'There is the sun in the sky and the spirit of the nation on earth. And the conscience in people's hearts can never be broken by any guns or swords. If people act according to their conscience, the earth will be full of justice, and the sun in the sky will shine even brighter.' The hall became an ocean of tears.

Librarian Son Jin-tae said, 'I had a dream last night where you all lifted me up and cheered hurrah while tossing me in the air. I was also cheering hurrah when I woke up startled to find it was a dream.' This was 'words with substance,' hinting at our country's independence.

After the farewell ceremony ended, we lit a bonfire with firewood in the playground in front of the main building and had our last drinks while eating 'curry rice' that Mrs. Lee A-ju had made by hand. We exploded our bitter resentment in a 'storm,' formed a scrum, and shouted the school cheer 'Sit Silent, Jaeho.' At that moment, someone shouted, 'Let's smash the Japanese police station.' We formed a protest group and left Anam-dong.

When the situation became serious, Principal Kim Seong-su urgently called me. 'These people will cause trouble. If you get excited and cause trouble, the school will be closed and even the underclassmen will have nowhere to learn.' He said, 'As there is today, there is also tomorrow. Rising from sorrow and washing away worries is our Korean people! Don't try to cut with a single stroke, but take a long view of everything.' I broke out in a cold sweat trying to turn the excited protest group back to school and settle things down.

▽The Student Soldier Encouragement Writing Was Not Directly Written by Inchon▽

On August 15, 1945, I heard Emperor Hirohito's unconditional surrender broadcast and came to Seoul on September 2 with my student soldier comrades to visit Inchon's home in Gye-dong [a neighborhood in Seoul]. The kind teacher was silent for a while, then sighed 'whew' and said as if to himself, 'Justice will prevail [sa-pil-gwi-jeong]' and warmly welcomed me, saying, 'Cheol-seung, you've returned alive.'

Inchon's Ulsan Kim clan and our Jeonui Lee clan had long social ties and in-law relationships [yeonsa]. My maternal grandmother was from the Ulsan Kim clan of Wolpyeong (Jangseong), Inchon's main family line.

I frequented the living rooms of Inchon and Han Hak-su, Baek Gwan-su, and Hwang Tae-mun in Gye-dong. Particularly, I was the youngest regular guest among the visitors to this house's living room, so I didn't refuse even the errand of carrying meal trays, learning the wisdom and every move of patriotic senior leaders in the chaotic night before nation-building after liberation.

At that time, I played the role of security chief guarding the Korean Democratic Party headquarters with representative elders of the nationalist camp who would participate in the Korean Democratic Party, especially Kim Seong-su, Baek Gwan-su, Won Se-dong, and Seo Sang-il.

When the school fell into the hands of the Korean People's Republic [Geongjun] and leftist vanguards, comrades like Yun Won-gu and Park Seok-gyu returned to school and earnestly urged my return. Particularly, Mrs. Lee A-ju, Inchon's wife, earnestly urged my return to school, so I returned to Bosung Professional's first professional department, political science third year in November 1945.

Nowadays, some call Inchon a pro-Japanese collaborator, but immediately after liberation, the Soviet military government and communists, to establish a red government, denounced Dr. Syngman Rhee as an American puppet and Inchon as a pro-Japanese collaborator. Even when I returned to my alma mater, leftist students following communist directives rejected Inchon as a pro-Japanese collaborator.

In 1988, some leftist elements from Korea University went down to Inchon's hometown of Gochang, North Jeolla Province, and painted the statue that provincial residents had erected to honor the teacher's noble national spirit, arousing the anger of North Jeolla residents.

In the same year, pro-North Juche ideology students [Korean student activists influenced by North Korean ideology] committed the unfilial act of binding with rope and trying to bury in a pit the statue built in Korea University's campus with donations from all alumni to honor the lofty intentions of founder Kim Seong-su.

I persuaded the students: 'Have you ever met Inchon? Have you ever learned from him? Half a century has passed since liberation, yet with what intention and basis can you call the eternal teacher and leader of our nation and founder of Korea University a landlord pro-Japanese collaborator? Do you know that even during Japanese rule, your grandparents revered Inchon as a national leader? Be careful that behind such shameless acts lies complicity with Kim Il-sung's group's conspiracy to destroy the legitimacy of the Republic of Korea.'

What leftists present as evidence for denouncing Inchon as a pro-Japanese collaborator is Inchon's student soldier encouragement writing published in Maeil Sinbo, the Government-General organ. Regarding this, Yu Jin-o clarifies in his book 'Yanghogi':

<After the student soldier volunteering commotion settled down and most applicable students went out as student soldiers, this time orders came down from the Government-General for certain figures to write articles encouraging student soldiers in newspapers. The only newspaper published in Korean at that time was Maeil Sinbo, the Government-General organ.

The person who conveyed that order to me was Kim Byeong-gyu, a Maeil Sinbo reporter. According to Kim, the writer list was directly selected by the Security Bureau: Kim Seong-su, Song Jin-u, Yeo Un-hyeong, An Jae-hong, Lee Gwang-su, Jang Deok-su, myself, and one or two others. It was almost a comprehensive roster of figures who could be said to have influence in Korean society at that time.

Inchon, who doesn't write, was the problem. Kim had apparently already met Inchon and said he would ghostwrite Inchon's article, to which Inchon replied, 'If it absolutely must be written, ghostwrite it, but be sure to show me what's written before publishing it.' When I confirmed by phone, Inchon's answer was to be careful not to make it a 'shameful article.'

Even saying the same thing, some people particularly like to use 'shameful' expressions. Since it was an article written reluctantly anyway, what difference would shameful or not shameful make, but still, while many people routinely showed excessive loyalty by saying 'Hakko Ichiu [all the world under one roof]' or 'Naisen Ittai [Japan and Korea as one],' Inchon, while unable to close the school doors against Japanese oppression, particularly disliked such 'shame.' It must have meant maintaining the national soul to the end even unto death.

Looking at the 'article not by Inchon but under Inchon's name' that Kim had ghostwritten, being talented, it was a modest article with hardly any 'shameful' expressions as feared. I wrote an article with the theme 'Korean youth's military service is an increase in Korean strength' and handed it over to Kim along with the article under Inchon's name.

I am now explaining the circumstances of how the student soldier encouragement articles came to be published, and particularly revealing even the real writer's name regarding the article under Inchon's name, because Inchon received severely unfair and unjust criticism from leftist forces after liberation due to those articles.>

▽Inchon Extremely Restrained from Political Participation▽

Inchon did not want political participation throughout his life. Inchon lived supporting only schools (Korea University), media (Dong-A Ilbo), and industry (Gyeongbang, etc.). He had Goha Song Jin-u, with whom he had a close friendship, engage in politics, but when Goha was harmed by Han Hyeon-u and the Korean Democratic Party fell into chaos, he was pushed forward as a 'central' figure to unite various factions and regional figures from the nationalist camp and inevitably became Korean Democratic Party representative.

When Vice President Lee Si-yeong resigned in protest of the Liberal Party regime's Geochang civilian massacre, National Defense Corps incident, and other human rights violations, incompetence, and corruption, Inchon was elected Vice President by the National Assembly. Then, seeing the political upheaval to scheme for the Liberal Party regime's long-term rule, he said, 'Even if the Vice President position is just holding a position without doing anything [si-wi-so-chan], the mere fact of having been Vice President under a dictatorial regime is shameful before the people,' and resigned from the Vice Presidency in 1952.

Inchon was sincere and calm, never engaging in political maneuvering and gestures like today. By showing the character of a pure grandfather and father at home, he made everyone, regardless of high or low status, feel close to him and treat him like a parent.

In 1947, when the Korea Track and Field Federation was asked to send athletes to the Boston International Marathon, they decided to send Seo Yun-bok from Geonkook Professional School, who held the best record at the time. I thought that if I could transfer Seo to Korea University and have him compete in the Boston Marathon, it could enhance Korea University's honor. Through earnest requests to Professor Kim Won-kwon in charge of physical education and senior Son Gi-jeong [1936 Olympic marathon gold medalist], I received approval for Seo's transfer to Korea University. I had Seo wear a Korea University uniform and run even before he became an official Korea University student. Seo Yun-bok won magnificently on April 19, 1947 (2 hours 25 minutes 39 seconds).

News of Seo Yun-bok's victory was featured prominently in American news agencies and newspapers, and Dr. Syngman Rhee even called Inchon to congratulate him.

I belatedly reported the circumstances to President Hyeon Sang-yun and pleaded for Seo's transfer to Korea University. However, President Hyeon refused, saying, 'The school has clear regulations, and I cannot tolerate you acting on your own like that.' I even argued back, 'Has there ever been such worldwide promotion of Korea University since the school's founding?' I then immediately visited Inchon and appealed desperately.

The teacher scolded me, saying, 'While the motive came from patriotic and school-loving sincerity, and the result also raised the honor of the country and school, which is good, the point of breaking school rules is clear.' Eventually, with Inchon's help, Seo could apply an exceptional provision allowing retroactive admission and formally enter Korea University.

▽Inchon Protected Bosung Professional with Great Righteousness▽

This also happened. The school authorities, having been upgraded to Korea University, made students from Bosung Professional's professional department take transfer exams. I demanded that the school give special consideration so that students who had contributed to protecting the campus by driving out the Communist Party that had caused campus disturbances including solidarity strikes would not fail the exams. I went to President Hyeon Sang-yun and Dean Yu Jin-o to appeal.

However, when my wishes were not accepted, I instigated comrades to steal the application forms as an emergency measure and gather at Gaeun Temple. This incident was immediately reported to Inchon, who was presiding over a Korean Democratic Party executive meeting, and he immediately rushed over saying, 'Where is Cheol-seung? Find Cheol-seung. Who else but Cheol-seung would do such a thing?' looking for me.

I was summoned before Inchon. He said, 'You helped overcome the school's crisis when you went as a student soldier in the past. I also know well that today's school reconstruction was due to your devoted contributions. Your contributions are admirable. But now are you planning to ruin the school?' speaking half pleadingly, half scolding.

I played dumb, scratching my head and denying knowing anything about such facts. However, seeing the teacher's dismayed appearance for the first time, I was scared and thought 'this is not good.' After a while, I said, 'I'll go find out,' and immediately went to Gaeun Temple to have the bundle of application forms returned, allowing the exams to be taken safely.

Due to this incident, our comrades who had worked hard for the Anti-Trusteeship Student League couldn't transfer to Korea University, like 'trying to remove a tumor but getting another one attached.' They almost all ended up joining the police. I also tried to quit school out of responsibility and loyalty to those comrades, but decided to continue staying at school, thinking of the overall position of student movements centered on the National Student Federation and the school as a whole.

Whenever our nation and the Republic of Korea face difficulties, I recall these several incidents and remember the image of the immortal national leader Inchon, who left great traces of patriotism and love for the nation, always trying to be with the people while being virtuous and gentle yet sincere and calm, and on the other hand, valuing great righteousness.

Lee Cheol-seung, Representative Standing Chairman of the Liberal Democratic National Conference"

In 1985, when I was driving freight trucks to experience the labor field, I often met with poet Park No-hae, who was working as a bus driver for the same reason. When the Guro Alliance Strike occurred that year, poet Park No-hae told me that the person who led that strike was Sim Sang-jung. That was the first time I heard my wife's name and learned what an amazing person she was. Then that winter, senior Kim Moon-soo said to me, 'It would be good if you and Sim Sang-jung met.' That senior didn't set us up, but hearing those words did make me more interested in my wife. Then in fall 1986, I first met my wife at a gathering of labor activists. At that time, my wife was a high-priority fugitive. The police had placed a bounty of 5 million won [approximately $12,500 USD at 1986 exchange rates] on her, with several ranks of promotion promised, viewing her as the mastermind behind the Guro Alliance Strike. Senior Kim Moon-soo had been taken to the Namyeong-dong [infamous interrogation center] by the security command due to the May 3 Incheon Uprising and wasn't at that gathering. When they tortured that senior, they apparently demanded 'Where is Sim Sang-jung?' Of course, since he didn't open his mouth, my wife wasn't captured.

▼ Former Governor Kim's recent actions are quite unexpected.
I think he's gone down a path that's too far astray. Looking at that senior brings up many different thoughts. In the past, he was a very authoritative and respected senior, a tremendous person, but seeing him today, it's regrettable that he seems to have become rather unsightly.

▼ What was your first impression of Representative Sim?
I had various fantasies about her because she was a fugitive and I had heard about her activities, but she had a neat appearance, neither big nor small. But watching her logically present her thoughts, I thought she was exactly as I had imagined.

▼ Did you feel attracted to her as the opposite sex?
I wasn't immediately smitten, but the following year in 1987, when the June Democratic Uprising occurred, I happened to meet her again briefly at a crosswalk in front of Seoul National University's medical school in Hyehwa-dong, Seoul. We both had appointments then, so we greeted lightly and parted, but since unions were being formed nationwide at that time, we met frequently at joint rallies and meetings from 1988 onward and began dating. Both Representative Sim and I later worked for organizations that supported labor unions. Representative Sim worked for the National Council of Trade Unions, which was formed in 1990, and I worked for the National Council of Labor Movement Organizations, which was established in 1988.

I asked her to date around 1989. In 1990, I was detained at the Namsan [location of former] KCIA as a member of the National Council of Labor Movement Organizations, and the interrogator asked me, 'Is Sim Sang-jung your girlfriend?' I played dumb and said I didn't know. Then he said, 'Do you know where you are to be lying like this? We've seen you two together.' They had conducted civilian surveillance. They had even taken photos, so I couldn't deny it. In the end, we became a couple recognized by the KCIA (laughs).

▼ What aspects of Representative Sim attracted you?
I felt that her convictions aligned well with my worldview and beliefs. What I particularly learned from Representative Sim was awareness of gender equality. The older seniors in the labor movement had patriarchal thoughts, viewing women merely as supporters who would take care of them, but meeting my wife changed my shallow gender consciousness significantly.

▼ How did you date?
Since we were poor lovers, when we occasionally met, our dates consisted of having tea and walking together. I remember Representative Sim found walking quite tiring.

▼ What did you call each other?
I called her 'Sang-jung-ssi,' and my wife called me 'senior.'

▼ Did you propose first too?
Yes. I proposed around 1991, but she didn't answer. We met at a coffee shop and I confessed with what I thought were nice words: 'Let's go together as lifelong companions. I want us to look ahead and walk together.' But my wife didn't answer, so our meetings became distant for quite some time. I thought, 'What's this? Doesn't she like me?' But it wasn't in my nature to approach aggressively either. As the waiting period got longer, I wondered if I should forget her, but then we confirmed each other's feelings. My wife also made up her mind and thought and planned a lot about the life we'd share together. She was in a hurry too. Hahaha.

▼ Did both families welcome your marriage?
At the time of marriage, I was 37 years old by Korean age, and my wife was 34. We were still bachelors and spinsters by those days' standards, so both families were thrilled. My father-in-law and mother-in-law were extremely happy. They seemed to have been very worried that my wife wasn't getting married.

▼ What kind of work did your parents do?
My father-in-law was an elementary school teacher, and my father was a small business owner. Both mothers were housewives. My wife's family had a relatively more liberal atmosphere than ours. Our family was economically poorer.

▼ There must have been interesting episodes from the wedding and honeymoon.
We held our wedding in fall 1992 at Suwoon Hall behind Hollywood Theater in Nakwon-dong, Seoul, and many guests came, perhaps because we married late. Then we went to Jeju Island for our honeymoon with a junior couple. A college junior who was a year below me had married and even had a child but couldn't have a wedding ceremony, which seemed to become a source of regret. Taking advantage of our wedding, that junior also got to have a honeymoon that wasn't quite a honeymoon. Back then, unlike now when there are many travel packages, that junior knew someone in Jeju Island who helped us a lot. Best of all, we could see unique places that only Jeju natives knew about (laughs).

▼ You worked in publishing and planning after marriage.
Around the time I got married, world history was undergoing dramatic changes. People who had been involved in the National Council of Labor Movement Organizations either sought different paths or looked for new directions suitable for the changes. While the National Council of Trade Unions that Representative Sim belonged to continued to thrive, our organization split and I had nothing to do. At that time, I took over the operation of a small, ownerless publishing company related to Representative Sim. I thought of it as an extension of my previous work. I had gotten married and needed to make a living somehow. I thought I would return to labor activism someday, but things didn't work out as planned. Even giving my all, success was uncertain, and since I hadn't started with firm resolve, I couldn't concentrate well on publishing work. Still, I did publishing and planning work for about 10 years, until the early 2000s.

▼ We heard that after Representative Sim became a Democratic Labor Party lawmaker in 2004, you took charge of all household affairs.
At that time, the Democratic Labor Party had just entered the parliament for the first time, so it wasn't well-organized, and since there were only first-term lawmakers in the party, there were no seniors to share know-how. Representative Sim had to create everything anew, so there was really a lot to do. So I handled everything from household affairs to sometimes acting as secretary and aide. I considered that my given role. Since I hadn't stepped forward with clear intentions to do politics myself, I became a househusband to firmly establish at least one person. I judged that helping Representative Sim work well was most important. Looking at things now, there are really many people who want to realize their demands or aspirations through Sim Sang-jung. They're supporters who empathize with and support Representative Sim's intentions. Since she has supporters, Representative Sim isn't just an individual. My job is to find and do things that can help such a Representative Sim.

▼ Haven't you only done housework since becoming a househusband?
While I do housework, I don't devote myself entirely to domestic affairs. I work or have side jobs, sometimes we're dual-income. Before my wife entered the National Assembly, I did laundry and dishes while my wife did cooking and meal preparation, but after my wife started legislative activities, I took over all those tasks.

▼ What are the hardships of being a househusband?
There are many people who are really good at housekeeping, so I wonder if I dare use the term 'househusband.' I'm unqualified. I mostly just take care of my own meals at home. However, during periods of dual income, we had many difficulties with childcare. Even when we left our child at daycare, it was impossible to match the closing time. It was exhausting for both of us. I thought our child would be very stressed, so later we left the child with my wife's family and visited on weekends. When our child was in elementary school, we had him stay at a junior colleague's house nearby after school. I felt sorry for our child, but we both had to work then, so there was no choice.

▼ Who manages household expenses?
I do. When Representative Sim brings home her parliamentary salary, I use it for household management and raising our child, and I cover shortfalls by working side jobs.

▼ What takes up the largest portion of living expenses?
Probably our child's education costs. He hasn't finished his studies yet. Our son graduated from Ewoo School (an alternative school), spent a year as a repeat test-taker [a student retaking CSAT after high school graduation], and entered Kyung Hee University's philosophy department. He's now a senior. He'll probably go to the military after graduation.

▼ Was there a special reason for sending your son to an alternative school?
Perhaps because our child didn't receive much parental care from a young age, he wasn't very bright when he entered the upper grades of elementary school during adolescence. So we sent him to an alternative school instead of a regular middle school. While academic competitiveness might be lower since they don't focus on entrance exams, the atmosphere is free and allows diverse experiences, which seemed like a good fit for our child. When we sent our child to that school, we also moved to Suji, Yongin, Gyeonggi Province, near the school. His interest in humanities grew there, which led him to choose philosophy for university, and now he shows deep interest in social issues.

Representative Sim usually wakes up at 5:30 AM and leaves the house before 6 AM. She mostly comes home after 10 PM. So I don't talk to her much at home. She talks with many people outside, and when she comes home exhausted, I shouldn't tire her out further. She needs to recharge to go out and be active the next day, so aside from absolutely necessary conversations, we don't talk much.

▼ How many points would you give Representative Sim as a wife and mother?
Since I handle our household affairs, judging by her work outside the home, I'd give her about 95 points. Our son also considers his mother a role model. She tries to do her job uprightly and sincerely. Even though she doesn't have much time with family, when she's home, she tries to make one more stew for the two men in the house.

▼ What dish does Representative Sim cook well?
She makes seasoned crab well and is confident about it. She makes it well by kneading it with her hands.

▼ You must be a popular 'yoseknam' (man who cooks well) these days.
When I'm with my son, I make kimchi stew or army stew quite well, but my skills aren't extraordinary. If I had someone to eat my homemade meals three times a day, I think I'd enjoy cooking and want to learn properly, but both my wife and son leave early in the morning and mostly solve meals by eating out. I often eat alone, so I just eat with rice, kimchi, and seaweed, or grill some fish and make do.

▼ Listening to your story, it seems you and your wife rarely fight.
Can married couples have no disagreements at all? Living together, we know what irritates each other, so we avoid those things. No couple is 100% satisfied with each other. Living together, you're bound to see shortcomings. For example, my inability to clean thoroughly might seem inadequate to Representative Sim, and I might have various feelings about Representative Sim too, but thinking rationally, since it's not problematic enough, I don't bother mentioning it. For instance, there are cases where my wife's and my perspectives differ and our views clash, and it's due to remaining male-centered thinking.

▼ What if your roles were reversed?
If my wife became the husband, she probably wouldn't be patriarchal. I don't think she'd have excessive expectations of her spouse either (laughs).

▼ How do your parents view their son living as a househusband?
Naturally, they had expectations for me, so they could say, 'You could do politics too, why don't you?' These days, some residents in the district (Ilsan Deokyang-gu) say the same thing, but if I hadn't married at all, it would be different, but since someone needs to be the foundation for another person to stand, my parents understand. Now my mother thinks very proudly of my wife as a daughter-in-law. My late father felt the same way.

▼ What kind of external support do you provide outside the home?
I do civic activities for district residents and other civic movements related to the Justice Party. I also think that's important external support I should provide.

▼ When was the most difficult time in your married life?
I started publishing business around the time we married in 1992 and did it for about 10 years, but when the 1997 foreign exchange crisis hit, we faced difficulties. The business didn't completely collapse, but sales dropped and debt accumulated, making recovery difficult. At that time, Representative Sim continued union work, but such problems put pressure on our lives, making things very tough.

▼ How did you overcome that crisis?
Thanks to help from people around us and cooperation, the problem was resolved around 2003, just before Representative Sim entered the National Assembly. After that, while exploring other career paths, I once thought about becoming a traditional Korean medicine doctor, but I gave up after my wife entered politics. I judged it wasn't time to start new ventures. I still think my choice then wasn't bad.

▼ When she failed to be reelected in 2008, what comfort did you give Representative Sim?
In a country with representative democracy, being outside the National Assembly reduces a politician's sphere of activity, so I said, 'Let's work in the district for four years and start again. There's so much work for us to do in this world.' Afterward, Representative Sim worked with local residents to create a village school, giving lectures, planning, and carrying out activities needed in the community.

▼ How did you feel when Representative Sim, who re-entered the National Assembly in 2012, resigned from her co-representative position taking responsibility for the Unified Progressive Party's proportional representation primary fraud scandal?
At that time, the biggest faction within the Unified Progressive Party was the old Democratic Labor Party faction represented by Lee Jung-hee. The next biggest faction was the People's Participation Party faction represented by Yoo Si-min, and the Sim Sang-jung-Roh Hoe-chan faction was the smallest. The three factions united in a co-representative system to consolidate power, but chemical homogenization between the two large factions was difficult. That problem manifested in the proportional representation primary fraud. Since Representative Sim had no way to resolve that problem, she resigned from the co-representative position. Thanks to that, I think the newly created Justice Party could establish in voters' minds the perception that it's constitutionally different from the Unified Progressive Party, which was dissolved in 2014.

▼ Recently, presidential candidates compared their images to food, which became a topic. What food could Representative Sim Sang-jung be compared to?
Sim Sang-jung is salt. She has consistently worked with conviction to prevent this society from rotting, and she plays the role of seasoning to meet the times by presenting policies our society needs at each moment, so I think she resembles salt.

▼ What do you think Representative Sim did best as a politician?
Raising issues about chaebol [large conglomerate] problems, industrial accidents involving female Samsung Electronics workers with leukemia, and humidifier disinfectant damage—bringing attention to people's suffering in daily life—these were all good works. But above all, I want to emphasize her consistent pursuit of the importance of modern democratic parties. It's really problematic when parties, which are the subjects of representative democracy, don't accurately read the will of the sovereign people and use top-down nomination processes. Representative Sim wants to create proper parties and do politics that well serves public opinion.

▼ What kind of country does Representative Sim dream of for Korea?
She wants to create a country where anyone who works hard is rewarded, a country where such people are happy. That's why she compressed this presidential election's slogan into 'Democracy with Labor.' She also dreams of a Korea where peace is established on the Korean Peninsula without the danger of war and exists within mutually beneficial international relations.

▼ If Representative Sim is elected president, what would you like to do as 'First Gentleman'?
If that happens, I think that would be the day our country becomes a 'advanced welfare state.' It would be a time when we wouldn't need to envy other countries. When that time comes, capable talents will fulfill their roles in appropriate positions, so would someone like me really be necessary? If there's any errand work to do, maybe I could do that. If such a day really comes, I'd like to work on environmental issues for the future of humanity.

▼ Do you have a life motto that serves as your compass?
(Pointing to calligraphy reading 'Like the First Time' hanging on the office wall) This is calligraphy by teacher Shin Yeong-bok [prominent Korean intellectual and calligrapher] meaning not to lose one's initial intentions. Looking at his calligraphy and contemplating its meaning puts my mind at ease. I also like the saying 'Yugong Yisan' [The Foolish Old Man Removes the Mountains]. It means you can achieve anything if you work steadily and diligently. I also took to heart words spoken by a history teacher while teaching Chinese history. It's from a writing by Fan Zhongyan [Chinese scholar-official], a military strategist and prime minister during the Song Dynasty, which can be expressed in four Chinese characters as 'Seonwoo Huwak' [Worry First, Enjoy Later]. It means 'A scholar should worry about the world's concerns before others and enjoy the world's pleasures after others.' I think it's something public officials must engrave in their hearts (laughs).

As we concluded the interview, we asked about his wishes for this year. He answered without hesitation: 'For the wishes of the candlelight public sentiment to be fulfilled.'

'Current domestic and international situations are bad, and people's lives are tough. Until the Constitutional Court's impeachment ruling comes out, I earnestly hope that the good public sentiment waiting patiently, though frustrated, won't be betrayed. I hope this situation is resolved quickly as the candlelight public sentiment wishes, and national affairs become stable.'"

The faces of Park Chan-ik (front row, left) and Jo So-ang (back row, second from left), who organized the Korean Independence Army in Manchuria in 1919, are visible. Dong-A Ilbo DB

《While the February 8 Independence Declaration conspiracy was in full swing in Tokyo, Japan, secret orders from the Dongje Society were also delivered to Manchuria, China. Jo So-ang, who had been in despair over the divisions among Manchurian independence movement groups that each acted as separate heroes, was hiding in seclusion in Jilin...》

On January 24, 1919 (December 23, 1918 by the lunar calendar), agent Jeong Won-taek (1890-1971), who had received secret orders from Shin Gyu-sik, leader of Shanghai's secret organization Dongje Society [Tongji Society], left Fengtian and infiltrated Jilin. This was when Dongje Society agents in charge of Japan were busy conspiring with Korean students in Tokyo for the February 8 Independence Declaration. Jeong Won-taek also had to succeed in organized independence activities centered in the Jilin region of Manchuria. Only then could they provide strength to Korean representatives like Kim Gyu-sik who had been dispatched to the Paris Peace Conference.

Jeong Won-taek, a graduate of the Dongje Society's educational institution Pakdal Academy, met senior comrade Park Chan-ik (1884-1949) at a Chinese inn (客棧, Chinese lodging facility) in Jilin Province. Jeong Won-taek showed Park Chan-ik Shin Gyu-sik's secret message and mentioned confidential independence declaration activities in various regions including America, Shanghai, Japan, and Korea.

Seeing Shin Gyu-sik's secret message, Park Chan-ik missed the 'stylish elder brother' Shin Gyu-sik from Shanghai with his black sunglasses and Kaiser mustache. Park Chan-ik had met Shin Gyu-sik and sworn brotherhood when he attended the government industrial training school in Korea. In 1909, Shin Gyu-sik was the president and editor of the magazine 'Industrial World,' launched to promote industrial development in the Korean Empire, while Park Chan-ik was the publisher.

Park Chan-ik and Jeong Won-taek decided to rally independence activists from West and North Jiandao according to Shin Gyu-sik's secret orders and carry out independence activities.

First, Jeong Won-taek contacted Jo So-ang (Jo Yong-eun, 1887-1958) through coded messages using postal boxes at post offices. This was a method of writing codes that only Dongje Society agents could understand on postcards and sending them to communication addresses. (From Jeong Won-taek's diary 'Jisan Foreign Travel Diary' - all dates mentioned below are lunar calendar dates converted to the solar calendar)

○ The Conflicted Thinker

On January 26, Jeong Won-taek made contact with Jo So-ang, who was staying at a Taoist temple (道館, Taoist temple) in a remote area outside the east gate of Jilin Province. Seeing that he had made a Taoist temple his residence, this was indeed 'very much like So-ang.' Jo So-ang, with his notably large head, exuded the aura of a religious figure or thinker, unlike what one would expect from a Meiji University law graduate.

Chunwon Yi Gwang-su described his time living with Jo So-ang in Shanghai in 1913: 'He (Jo So-ang) would sit quietly on his bed reading the Quran, or otherwise sit with his eyes half-closed, swaying his body left and right.' (Yi Gwang-su's 'My Confession')

At that time, Jo So-ang was active as a teacher at Pakdal Academy operated by the Dongje Society, and whenever he had spare time, he would study world religions including Islam and philosophy, or enjoy meditation. In 1914, as part of the independence movement, he conceived an original religion called Yukseong-gyo [Six Saints Religion] that worshipped Dangun [legendary founder of Korea] and six sages from East and West, and even wrote religious texts called 'Ilsin-gyo-ryeong' [Monotheistic Religious Command]. So it wasn't particularly strange that Jo So-ang was staying at a Taoist temple where Taoist masters resided.

The weather in Jilin was still deep winter. The two men drank warm ginseng tea and shared their feelings after meeting for a long time. There had been an occasion when Jo So-ang was arrested by Chinese police in Manchuria as a suspicious person, and Jeong Won-taek had actively stepped forward to help him. After sharing various personal stories and finishing a cup of tea, Jeong Won-taek brought up the main topic.

'Now, following communication instructions from Teacher Ye-gwan [Shin Gyu-sik], I am carrying some documents to rally Manchurian comrades and correspond secretly with the Russian territory [Maritime Province]. This is the important responsibility that Nam-pa [Park Chan-ik] and So-ang must undertake.'

Jeong Won-taek urged swift action, saying time was urgent. However, the reaction of Dongje Society agent Jo So-ang was unexpected.

'When I came here from West Jiandao, I had made a resolution. I decided to hide in this Taoist temple from now on, not interfere with worldly affairs, not argue with people, and simply cultivate myself alone. Leave me be.'

Jo So-ang spoke calmly. Jeong Won-taek was shocked by these unexpected words. Wasn't this Jo So-ang, who had consistently carried out independence activities with Shin Gyu-sik from early on? His older brother Jo Yong-ha had gone into exile in China after the 1905 Eulsa Treaty was concluded and was conducting independence activities in Manchuria and America, while his younger brother Jo Yong-ju had also followed his brother (Jo So-ang) into exile and was active as an independence activist. Yet here he was, saying he would now quietly cultivate himself in seclusion.

At that time, Jo So-ang was in anguish.

'As World War I was drawing to a close, overseas Korean communities had not even a hair's breadth of hope for unity, and the masses at home were also quietly without any sound. My heart was very anxious, so I resolved to rally Koreans in the Northeast region and went there alone. At that time, the big figures in the Korean expatriate community were each acting as heroes and maintaining separate territories, so there was no hope for unification and it ended in failure. Thus I secluded myself in Jilin Province and read books.' (Jo So-ang's 'Autobiography,' published in 1943)

In an essay he wrote after returning to Korea in 1946, reflecting on the period before and after the March 1st Movement of 1919, he recorded:

'I deeply lamented and was disappointed by our nation's lack of unity. However, this was my hasty judgment and miscalculation. When that spirit matured and the timing was seized, I discovered and learned from the March 1st Movement that there is no nation with stronger unity than ours.' (Jo So-ang's 'The March 1st Movement and I,' Jayu Shinmun, February 26, 1946)

Until the flames of the March 1st Revolution ignited at home, Jo So-ang had moved beyond skepticism to almost despair about the inability of people of the same blood to unite.

○ The Original Independence Declaration: The Daedong Unity Declaration

The Daedong Unity Declaration (left photo), with 14 independence activists including Shin Jeong (Shin Gyu-sik) and Jo Yong-eun (Jo So-ang) listed as initiators, is evaluated as the original independence declaration. The seal of the Dongje Society that led the Daedong Unity Declaration. Provided by Independence Hall of Korea and Gyeonggi Provincial Museum

Jo So-ang had good reason for this. His 'Declaration of Daedong Unity' (Daedong Unity Declaration), which contained his political beliefs, had returned as an empty echo despite countless efforts.

In July 1917, Jo So-ang drafted the Daedong Unity Declaration with comrades in Shanghai and distributed it to independence movement organizations at home and abroad. It was a declaration calling for convening domestic and international representative conferences to organize an institution called 'Musang-beopin' [Supreme Legal Person], namely a government, based on the principle that Daedong unity was essential for the independence movement above all else.

Key figures of the Dongje Society were listed as initiators of the declaration. Led by Dongje Society leader Shin Gyu-sik, there were 14 people including Jo So-ang, Shin Seok-u, Park Yong-man, Park Eun-sik, Shin Chae-ho, Jo Seong-hwan, Kim Gyu-sik, and Yun Se-bok. Given that it was a declaration signed by renowned independence activists, its weight was considerable.

Particularly, the Daedong Unity Declaration drafted by Jo So-ang contained content publicly and officially declaring that the sovereignty of the (Korean Empire) emperor had been transferred to the people. It clearly stated that the national polity to be established after national independence would be a nation of popular sovereignty, not a monarchical restoration.

'The day when Emperor Yunghui [Sunjong] abandoned the three treasures [land, people, politics] - August 29 of the year Gyeongsul (1910) - is the very day our comrades inherited them, for not a moment did we stop breathing during that time. Our comrades are complete heirs, so the time of imperial authority's extinction is the time of popular rights' birth, and the last day of old Korea is the first day of new Korea. Why is this so? Our great Korea has been Korea for Koreans, not for non-Koreans, since time immemorial. The giving and receiving of sovereignty among Koreans is an unwritten constitutional law in history. The transfer of sovereignty to non-Koreans is fundamentally invalid and absolutely impermissible to Korea's national character.' ('Daedong Unity Declaration')

This was also a 'revolutionary' declaration that clearly presented the goals and direction of the independence movement, which had been stagnant at the time. In fact, when the Daedong Unity Declaration was published, the independence movement at home and abroad was facing its worst situation.

In 1911, as part of military rule, Japan fabricated an assassination attempt on Joseon Governor-General Terauchi Masatake and arrested en masse leaders of the Sinminhoe [New People's Association] organized by Ahn Chang-ho, Yi Dong-nyeong, Yi Seung-hun, and others. The Sinminhoe, an anti-Japanese nationalist organization in the northwestern region, was completely disbanded. This was the so-called '105-Person Incident.' Due to this incident, independence activists based domestically fled overseas, with Yi Seung-man going to America and Kim Gyu-sik to China. Subsequently, domestic resistance organizations like the Independence Army (1912-1914) and the Korean Restoration Association (1915-1918) were discovered one after another, leading to the collapse of the righteous army movement.

Overseas conditions were also difficult. In 1915, Yi Sang-seol, Shin Gyu-sik, and others established the New Korea Revolutionary Party in China and attempted to create an exile government supporting Emperor Gwangmu [Gojong], but this was also discovered and came to nothing. It was around this time that a declaration completely ending the pro-imperial [bohwang] line of independence movement strategy centered on the Korean Empire's emperor was published.

Jo So-ang, who drafted the Daedong Unity Declaration, judged that since the duties and rights of the three treasures belonged to the people, a subject to exercise them was necessary. Since domestic compatriots were currently constrained by Japanese rule, overseas comrades must bear that responsibility, and for this purpose, he proposed that national representatives from various overseas regions hold conferences to establish the sole supreme institution. (Jo Dong-geol's 'The 1917 Daedong Unity Declaration for Establishing the Provisional Government')

This declaration later became the foundation for the independence declaration of the March 1st Movement and the establishment of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea. This is also why Shin Gyu-sik, director of the Dongje Society, and Park Eun-sik, president, named the Daedong Unity Declaration the 'First Shanghai Proclamation' in the inaugural issue of the weekly magazine 'Jindan' published in 1920, the year after the March 1st Movement, defining it as the first independence declaration.

However, the response when the declaration was actually published was disappointing. Although the declaration would have been widely known through 'Sinhan Minbo' (North America), 'Gungmin-bo' (Hawaii), 'Hanin Shinbo' (Vladivostok), 'Cheonggu Shinbo' (Ussuriysk), almost no organizations responded. Jo So-ang was considerably disappointed.

Jo So-ang then went to China's Northeast region in 1918 to attempt unification of independence movement organizations based on Korean expatriate communities. This also failed. As he put it, not a single organization that acted as separate heroes responded.

This was a point that Dongje Society agent Park Chan-ik also felt.

'Saying that military activities with armed force were important in the independence movement, everyone created armed organizations. Even someone with a few subordinates boasted of being an independence army commander, and those with 100 or 1,000 people also each showed off as independence army commanders. Even while walking the same path, each put forward their own theories and were reluctant to become one.' ('Biography of Nam-pa Park Chan-ik')

○ 'The Opportunity to Make a Great Outcry Again Has Come'

Jeong Won-taek persuaded Jo So-ang, who said he would live by cultivating his spirit.

'Whether it's me, you [Jo So-ang], or various other comrades, the reason we abandoned parents, wives, and children after the national humiliation and sweetly endured hardships and suffering while sleeping rough in the wind and rain in distant lands was all based on the saying that if one has will, it will eventually be achieved, awaiting the right time. Now the war clouds in the West have cleared for the first time and peace conferences are opening in Paris, with weak nations proclaiming self-determination. Though the work may be imperfect, the time has come. Don't calculate the success or failure of the work - this is the opportunity to rise once and make a great outcry. If we miss this opportunity, when will we wait for another? Secluded cultivation won't be too late even when old.'

Finally, Jo So-ang's heart was moved. Jeong Won-taek and Jo So-ang met together with Park Chan-ik, who was staying at an inn, then discussed activity plans at the house of Yeo Jun (1862-1932) outside the north gate of Jilin Province.

At the end of February 1919, independence activists from West and North Jiandao secretly gathered at the house of Yeo Jun, former principal of Shinheung Military Academy. Some came after hearing rumors to contribute funds for the cause. Because his mother is Russian, he had the opportunity to attend the 'LG Love Multicultural School' operated by KAIST. Here he discovered his interests and entered the nation's only maister high school [specialized vocational high school] for robotics and mechanical control. He has already decided on a plan to study mobile robotics in the future.

The Convergence Education Research Center under KAIST's Natural Science Research Institute, which helped him, has been operating the Love Multicultural School convergence talent program with LG since 2010. Last year, a total of 67 elementary, middle, and high school students participated. Thirty students visit KAIST directly once a month to attend classes. They conduct experimental classes divided by elementary, middle, and high school levels.

Eleven KAIST mentors helped with hands-on classes where students directly set up volcanic eruption experiments or created desert oases, water rockets, and gene chips.

Thirty elementary school students who had difficulty coming to KAIST directly received online education. Tablet PCs were provided to all, and materials for experiments were sent in 'science boxes.' The center has consistently had students participate in science expos since 2010. Interest is high because of the experiential education. Last year, the attendance rate for second-term students was 94% offline and 89% online.

The convergence talent program is characterized not by simply supporting students, but by developing their aptitude in science and engineering fields in a customized manner. Of the 18 students who entered high school through this program, 9 achieved the success of entering special purpose schools including Changwon Science High School or autonomous private high schools.
